s.text: But by the end, the performance makes sense: It's as if she's scything her way home through a thicket of her own unmanageable emotions--and she gets there.
(I refrain from saying what I think after most movies not because I want to tantalize people but because I reserve the right to change my mind in the course of writing a review.)
(I refrain from saying what I think after most movies not because I want to tantalize people but because I reserve the right to change my mind in the course of writing a review.)

You treat The Green Mile as if it's a humanist milestone on the order of To Kill a Mockingbird . But it has been more than a third of a century since Mockingbird 's Great White Father and that shambling, saintly black martyr who pays for the sex crimes of white men--and in-between came the civil-rights movement.
But there have still been a ton of great female performances.
Better than a mute, I might add: She is a mute who does laundry.
